bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, March 31, 1900

div1.p: Lazear writes that his workload will be lighter after Reed leaves. He reports that his son is well.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, March 31, 1900
div1.p:
I have been busy
all this week but Dr. Reed leaves
today so I shall have it a
little lighter for a while. It has
been rather warm but one feels
all right if one does not
exercise hard in the middle of the
day. We visited Morro Castle and
Cabañas yesterday. They are old
fortresses like the one at St. Augustine
except much larger. I was much
surprised at the size of Cabañas It
I think it has more rooms in it
than any building I have ever seen.

The Spaniards have quartered 10 000 troops
there. At present it is not used
at all owing to the danger of
Yellow Fever. It is situated directly
across the harbor from Havana.

The Spaniards used it also as a
prison and there are numerous
horrible dungeons under it.

In the moat is a place where
they shot the prisoners.
Along the wall there is a
black line about four feet from
the ground which was used
as a guide to the soldiers in
taking aim.

The baby is doing very well
now. For some reason the
fleas suddenly disappeared and
consequently he sleeps much
better. He received your
letter and will probably be able
to understand it some day.
He has not yet spoken a word,
but he thinks he can talk and
makes lots of noise that seems
to give him great satisfaction.
He is out of doors almost
all the time. We have a nice
porch with a railing and
he stays there when not
off in his carriage.

We enjoyed the “Bookman” you
sent very much. I hope you
will send some more, but not
until you have finished reading
them.

I have not heard a word from
Pittsburgh since I came here.
The rents of course are being saved
to pay taxes which fall due
in April so there was not
much to write about,

The house on Denniston Ave
will be vacant after Apr 1.
unless a new tenant is secured.
They are advertising. I am not sorry
that the present tenant is leaving
Like most preachers, he was
more nuisance than anything
else. It is rather amusing
to see the treatment of the
Chaplain here. a Presbyterian
minister. No one seems to
want him around. He has been
refused admission to most
of the messes.
I hope to hear from you soon.
div1.closer:
Your affectionate Son I have just heard from the Brandts.
They say that the Halls want to keep the
house until May 1 and that they think
they have a man who will take it
unfurnished from that time. Consequently
nothing need be done at present and Mabel
will probably be on hand at the time
the furniture is to be taken out-
J. W. L.
